questions.title: Credit Migration Expected Return
questions.question: Mark Jackson holds a BB-rated bond with YTM of 4.0% and modified duration of 5.0. Based on the credit transition matrix, there is a 50% probability of upgrading to BBB (spread narrows by 40 bps) and a 50% probability of downgrading to B (spread widens by 100 bps). What is the expected 1-year total return?
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate price return for EACH scenario

Upgrade to BBB (spread narrows 40 bps):
Return = -Duration × Δspread = -5.0 × (-0.40%) = +2.00%

Downgrade to B (spread widens 100 bps):
Return = -Duration × Δspread = -5.0 × (+1.00%) = -5.00%

Step 2: Probability-weight the scenario returns
E(price return) = 0.50 × (+2.00%) + 0.50 × (-5.00%)
= +1.00% - 2.50% = -1.50%

Step 3: Add YTM for total expected return
Total return = YTM + E(price return)
= 4.0% + (-1.50%) = 2.50%

Trap answers:
• A (4.00%): Forgot to calculate price impact from migration
• C (-1.50%): Only calculated price return, forgot to add YTM
• D (5.50%): Added price return instead of subtracting
keyFormulas: Each scenario: Return = -Duration × Δspread
E(price return) = Σ(Prob × scenario return)
Total return = YTM + E(price return)
questions.yourMistake: Either forgot to weight the migrations, forgot YTM, or got the sign wrong on spread widening

questions.title: ABS Credit Analysis Approaches
questions.question: Jackson analyzes a commercial ABS collateralized by short-term loans to small US retailers. The loan pool is granular (many small loans) and homogeneous (similar characteristics). Which credit analysis approach is most suitable?
questions.explanation:
Pool Characteristics → Approach:

• Small + Heterogeneous → Loan-by-loan (few unique loans worth individual analysis)
• Medium-term + Dynamic → Portfolio-based (pool composition changes over time)
• Short-term + Granular + Homogeneous → Statistics-based (aggregate stats suffice)

The key triggers were 'short-term,' 'granular,' and 'homogeneous' — all pointing to statistics-based.
questions.yourMistake: Chose portfolio-based (for dynamic pools) instead of statistics-based (for static, homogeneous pools)

questions.title: CDS Cheapest-to-Deliver
questions.question: Jackson owns $20M face value of Bond X and bought $20M notional CDS protection. Upon default, Bond X trades at 40% of par and Bond Y (also deliverable) trades at 35% of par. What are Jackson's total proceeds from both positions?
questions.explanation:
• Bond X value: $20M × 40% = $8M
• CDS payoff uses cheapest-to-deliver (Bond Y at 35% = lower price = higher loss)
• CDS payoff: $20M × (1 - 35%) = $20M × 65% = $13M
• Total: $8M + $13M = $21M

CTD = bond with LOWEST market value. Protection buyer benefits from referencing the cheapest bond even if they own a different one.
keyFormulas: CDS Payoff = Notional × (1 - Recovery Rate of CTD)
CTD = bond with lowest market value (highest loss)
questions.yourMistake: Used Bond X's recovery rate (40%) instead of CTD Bond Y's rate (35%)

questions.title: Rolling Down the Yield Curve
questions.question: Michael Eng expects spot rates to remain unchanged. He holds a 3-year zero-coupon bond. Given: 1-year spot = 0.75%, 2-year spot = 1.20%, 3-year spot = 1.45%, and the implied forward rate f(2,1) = 1.95%. What is the first-year return on the 3-year bond?
questions.explanation:
If spot curve is unchanged, the 3-year bond 'rolls down' to become a 2-year bond after one year.

The return equals the forward rate for that period: f(2,1) = 1.95%

Mathematically: P₀ = 1/(1.0145)³, P₁ = 1/(1.0120)², Return = P₁/P₀ - 1 = 1.95%
keyFormulas: Rolling yield = forward rate for the period
3-year bond held 1 year earns f(2,1)
questions.yourMistake: Used 1-year spot rate (0.75%) instead of the forward rate

questions.title: Yield Curve Theories
questions.question: Client 1 restricts Eng to buy only bonds ≤3 years. Even though Eng expects 5-year bonds to have superior returns, he cannot deviate from this restriction. This is most consistent with which theory?
questions.explanation:
Theory comparison:

• Segmented Markets: Investors CANNOT/WILL NOT leave their maturity segment regardless of returns
• Preferred Habitat: Investors WILL leave for sufficient premium

Client has a hard restriction — Eng CANNOT buy 5-year bonds even with superior expected returns. This absolute inability to deviate = segmented markets.
keyFormulas: Preferred Habitat: 'I'll leave for enough premium'
Segmented Markets: 'I can ONLY invest here, period'
questions.yourMistake: Confused preferred habitat (will leave for premium) with segmented markets (cannot leave)

questions.title: Net Stable Funding Ratio
questions.question: An analyst evaluates a bank's liquidity using the Net Stable Funding Ratio (NSFR = Available Stable Funding / Required Stable Funding). Which change would INCREASE the bank's NSFR?
questions.explanation:
NSFR = Available Stable Funding / Required Stable Funding

• Numerator (ASF): Capital, long-term debt (>1yr), stable deposits
• Denominator (RSF): Loans, illiquid assets

Increase in long-term debt → higher ASF → higher NSFR
Increase in loans → higher RSF → lower NSFR
keyFormulas: NSFR = Available Stable Funding / Required Stable Funding
Higher ASF or Lower RSF → Higher NSFR

questions.title: Current Rate Method Translation
questions.question: Celeste (IFRS) translates US subsidiary Salto using the current rate method. Salto's revenue = USD 120M, COGS = USD 65M. Average rate = 43.26 UYU/USD, historical inventory rate = 42.81. What is translated gross profit in UYU?
questions.explanation:
Under current rate method, BOTH revenue and COGS use the average rate:

Gross Profit = (120M - 65M) × 43.26 = 55M × 43.26 = 2,379

Method comparison:
• Current Rate: Revenue = Average, COGS = Average
• Temporal: Revenue = Average, COGS = Historical
keyFormulas: Current Rate: All I/S items at average rate
Temporal: Monetary at current, non-monetary at historical
questions.yourMistake: Used temporal method logic (historical rate for COGS) when question specified current rate method

questions.title: Hyperinflation Translation IFRS
questions.question: Under IFRS, Celeste acquired a subsidiary in a hyperinflationary economy. After restating for inflation per IAS 29, how should the income statement be translated?
questions.explanation:
IFRS Hyperinflation (Two-Step):
1. Restate for inflation (IAS 29)
2. Translate ALL items at current end-of-period rate

After restatement, everything — BS and IS — uses current rate, NOT average.

Contrast with US GAAP: Just use temporal method for hyperinflationary subsidiaries.
keyFormulas: IFRS Hyperinflation: Restate → Translate all at current rate
US GAAP Hyperinflation: Use temporal method
questions.yourMistake: Thought average rate applies to I/S under hyperinflation

questions.title: SBC Excess Tax Benefit
questions.question: A company's stock price at vest date ($70) exceeds the grant-date price ($50) used for book expense. The tax deduction is based on vest-date value. What is the impact on tax expense?
questions.explanation:
If market price at vest > grant price:
• Tax deduction ($70) > Book expense ($50)
• Excess tax benefit → Decreases tax expense (windfall)

If market price at vest < grant price:
• Tax deduction < Book expense
• Tax shortfall → Increases tax expense

questions.title: DB Pension Expense US GAAP
questions.question: Given: Service cost = $200, Interest cost = $2,940, Expected return on assets = $3,120, Actual return = $2,700. Calculate the US GAAP pension expense (ignoring amortizations):
questions.explanation:
US GAAP Pension Expense = Service Cost + Interest Cost - Expected Return on Assets (± Amortizations)

Calculation:
= $200 + $2,940 - $3,120
= $20

Key differences between US GAAP and IFRS:
• US GAAP uses management's expected return on plan assets
• IFRS uses Net Interest approach (same discount rate applied to both PBO and plan assets)
• Under US GAAP, the difference between actual and expected return goes to OCI

Wrong answers:
• B ($440): Would result from using actual return instead of expected ($200 + $2,940 - $2,700)
• C ($2,740): Just Service + Interest, forgot to subtract expected return
• D (-$180): Calculation error
keyFormulas: US GAAP: Service + Interest - Expected Return ± Amortizations
IFRS: Service + Net Interest (discount rate × net pension liability)
questions.yourMistake: Used actual return instead of expected return, or forgot a component

questions.title: Full vs Partial Goodwill
questions.question: Apex (US GAAP) acquires 80% of Beast for $24M. FV of Beast's identifiable net assets = $25M, FV of entire Beast = $30M. How much goodwill should Apex recognize?
questions.explanation:
US GAAP requires FULL GOODWILL method:

Full Goodwill = FV of Entity - FV of Net Assets = $30M - $25M = $5M

Partial Goodwill (IFRS option only) = $24M - (80% × $25M) = $4M

US GAAP: Full only. IFRS: Choice of full or partial.
keyFormulas: Full Goodwill = FV of entity - FV of net assets
US GAAP = Full only; IFRS = Choice
questions.yourMistake: Calculated partial goodwill ($4M) but US GAAP requires full goodwill

questions.title: Residual Income Persistence
questions.question: A company's residual income persistence factor (ω = 0.12) is one-quarter of industry average (0.48). This low persistence is most consistent with:
questions.explanation:
Lower persistence (ω → 0) caused by:
• High dividend payout
• EXTREME levels of ROE (very high or very low)
• HIGH accounting accruals (lower earnings quality)

Higher persistence (ω → 1) = low dividends, moderate ROE, low accruals

High accruals suggest lower earnings quality → less sustainable RI → lower persistence.
questions.yourMistake: Thought low persistence meant lower returns, but it's EXTREME ROE and high accruals

questions.title: Finite-Horizon Residual Income
questions.question:
Using the finite-horizon RI model to value PrimaNet:

• Current book value (B₀): €18.50
• Residual income Year 1: €2.54
• Residual income Year 2: €2.54
• Forecasted book value at end of Year 2: €23.75
• Forecasted market price at end of Year 2: €26.50
• Cost of equity: 12.8%
• WACC: 6.5%

PrimaNet's intrinsic value per share is closest to:
questions.explanation:
V₀ = B₀ + Σ PV(RI) + PV(Terminal Premium)

Step 1: Discount each year's RI at cost of equity
PV of RI Year 1 = €2.54 / (1.128)¹ = €2.25
PV of RI Year 2 = €2.54 / (1.128)² = €2.00

Step 2: Calculate Terminal Premium = Market Price - Book Value
= €26.50 - €23.75 = €2.75

Step 3: Discount terminal premium at cost of equity (not WACC!)
PV = €2.75 / (1.128)² = €2.75 / 1.272 = €2.16

Step 4: Add it all up
V₀ = €18.50 + €2.25 + €2.00 + €2.16 = €24.91

Trap answers:
• B (€25.17): Uses WACC to discount terminal premium: €2.75 / (1.065)² = €2.42
• C (€27.33): Forgot to discount the RIs, just added raw values: €18.50 + €2.54 + €2.54 + €2.75 = €26.33
keyFormulas: V₀ = B₀ + Σ PV(RI) + (P_T - B_T)/(1+r)^T
Equity models → Discount at cost of equity, NOT WACC
RI must be discounted to PV before adding
questions.yourMistake: Either forgot to discount RI values, or used WACC instead of cost of equity

questions.title: Covered Interest Rate Parity
questions.question: Calculate 6-month forward USD/NZD. Spot = 0.6808, US 6-month rate = 0.50% annual, NZ 6-month rate = 1.00% annual. What is the forward rate?
questions.explanation:
F = S × (1 + r_price × period) / (1 + r_base × period)

Critical: Adjust annual rates to 6-month rates!
• 6-month US rate = 0.50% / 2 = 0.25%
• 6-month NZ rate = 1.00% / 2 = 0.50%

F = 0.6808 × (1.0025) / (1.005) = 0.6791
keyFormulas: F = S × (1 + r_price × t) / (1 + r_base × t)
Always match rate period to forward period!
questions.yourMistake: Used annual rates without adjusting for 6-month period

questions.title: Forward Contract Value at Time t
questions.question: Six months ago, you entered a 9-month forward contract to buy an asset at a forward price of F₀ = $105. The current spot price is S_t = $108, and the risk-free rate is 4% (annualized). The value of the long forward contract today is closest to:
questions.explanation:
V_t = S_t - F₀/(1+r)^(T-t)

Step 1: Determine time remaining
Original term = 9 months, time elapsed = 6 months
Time remaining = T - t = 3 months = 0.25 years

Step 2: Discount the forward price
F₀/(1+r)^(T-t) = 105/(1.04)^0.25 = 105/1.00985 = $103.97

Step 3: Calculate value
V_t = 108 - 103.97 = $4.03

Key: Use TIME REMAINING (T-t), not time elapsed.
Common mistake: Using 6 months (elapsed) → 105/(1.04)^0.5 = $102.94 → V = $5.06 (wrong)
keyFormulas: V_t = S_t - F₀/(1+r)^(T-t)
(T-t) = time remaining, not elapsed
questions.yourMistake: Used wrong time period for discounting

questions.title: VaR Types
questions.question: A risk manager wants to know how total portfolio VaR would change if she increases a position. Which VaR type measures this?
questions.explanation:
VaR Types:

• Incremental VaR: Change in VaR from adding/changing a position
• Marginal VaR: Per-unit change in VaR for small position change
• Component VaR: Contribution of a position to total portfolio VaR
• Conditional VaR (CVaR): Expected loss given VaR is exceeded

Memory: Incremental = 'What if I INCREMENT this position?'

questions.title: Information Coefficient and Active Weights
questions.question: Souza wants SMALLER optimal active weights. Which combination achieves this?

choices.text: Decrease in both IC and target active risk
Increase in IC and decrease in target active risk
Increase in both IC and target active risk
Decrease in IC and increase in target active risk

questions.explanation:
Effect on Optimal Active Weights:

• Higher IC → Smaller weights (better forecasts need less extreme bets)
• Lower target active risk → Smaller weights

For SMALLER weights: Higher IC AND Lower target risk (Answer B)

Counterintuitive: Higher skill means you don't need to bet as big!
questions.yourMistake: Thought lower IC reduces weights, but higher IC actually does

questions.title: Fundamental Law: Effect of Portfolio Constraints
questions.question: A prospective client's guidelines restrict maximum sector over/underweights. What is the most likely effect on the fundamental law components?
questions.explanation:
• IC = forecasting skill (not affected by constraints)
• Breadth = number of independent decisions (not affected)
• TC = ability to implement forecasts (REDUCED by weight limits)

Constraints don't change how many bets you make or your skill — they limit how much you can act on each forecast → lower TC.
questions.yourMistake: Thought constraints reduced breadth, but they reduce transfer coefficient

questions.title: Neoclassical Steady-State Growth
questions.question: Country A data: TFP growth = 2.1%, Labor share = 55.2%, Labor force growth = 0.9%. Calculate steady-state growth rate.
questions.explanation:
ΔY/Y = θ/(1-α) + n

where θ = TFP growth, (1-α) = Labor share, n = Labor growth

= 2.1% / 0.552 + 0.9%
= 3.8% + 0.9% = 4.7%

Common mistakes:
• θ + n directly = 3.0% ❌
• Divide by capital share = 5.6% ❌
• Forget to add n = 3.8% ❌
keyFormulas: Steady-state = θ/(1-α) + n
Divide TFP by LABOR share, then ADD labor growth
questions.yourMistake: Divided by capital share (0.448) instead of labor share (0.552)

questions.title: Currency Crisis Warning Signs
questions.question:
Bernard evaluates Country B for currency crisis risk. Which is a warning sign?

1. Slight decline in foreign equity investment
2. Broad money growth with declining M2/bank reserves ratio
3. Sizable decline in FX reserves relative to daily turnover
questions.explanation:
Currency Crisis Warning Signs:
• Declining FX reserves ✓ (burning through reserves to defend currency)
• Large capital INFLOWS (not outflows) preceding crisis
• RISING M2/bank reserves ratio (not declining)

Condition 2 is wrong because studies show M2/reserves ratio RISES before crisis, not declines.
questions.yourMistake: Confused declining M2/reserves ratio (not a warning) with rising ratio (warning sign)

questions.title: Cointegration Testing
questions.question: Silva tests cointegration between two series. H1: Series 1 has unit root. H2: Series 2 has unit root. H3: Regression residuals have unit root. For cointegration, which results are needed?

choices.text: Reject H1 and H2, fail to reject H3
Fail to reject H1 and H2, reject H3

questions.explanation:
Cointegration = Two non-stationary series whose combination IS stationary

• H1: Fail to reject (Series 1 IS non-stationary)
• H2: Fail to reject (Series 2 IS non-stationary)
• H3: REJECT (Residuals ARE stationary - no unit root)

Both series wander randomly, but their linear combination is stable.
keyFormulas: Cointegration: Both series have unit roots, residuals don't
questions.yourMistake: Thought all three should be rejected/failed

questions.title: Regression Residual Diagnostics
questions.question:
Silva runs an AR(1) model and tests residuals:
• Regression 1 (ε on lagged ε): t-stat = 0.70
• Regression 2 (ε² on lagged ε²): t-stat = 2.94
Critical value = 1.97. Is the model misspecified?
questions.explanation:
Two Different Tests:

• Regression 1 (ε on lagged ε) → Tests serial correlation → 0.70 < 1.97 = NOT significant
• Regression 2 (ε² on lagged ε²) → Tests ARCH → 2.94 > 1.97 = SIGNIFICANT

ARCH present = variance of errors is not constant = model misspecified
keyFormulas: ARCH test: Regress squared residuals on lagged squared residuals
Serial correlation test: Regular residuals
questions.yourMistake: Only looked at Regression 1 (serial correlation), missed Regression 2 (ARCH)

questions.title: ML Feature Selection
questions.question: Silva builds a text classifier. For feature selection, which tokens should be KEPT?
questions.explanation:
Feature Selection:

• High TF: REMOVE — likely stop words ('the', 'and')
• High DF: REMOVE — appears everywhere, no discriminating power
• High MI: KEEP — strongly associated with one class

Mutual Information measures how much a token helps classify. High MI = token appears mostly in one specific class = valuable feature.
questions.yourMistake: Chose high DF (appears everywhere = useless) instead of high MI (discriminates classes)

questions.title: Commodity Futures Total Return
questions.question:
An analyst calculates the total return on a commodity futures investment over 4 months.

Given:
• Previous spot price: $100
• Current spot price: $105
• Near-term futures closing price: $104
• Far-term futures closing price: $100
• Risk-free rate: 3% annual

The total return on the investment is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Total Return = Price Return + Roll Return + Collateral Return

Step 1: Price Return
= (Current price – Previous price) / Previous price
= ($105 – $100) / $100 = 5.00%

Step 2: Roll Return
= (Near-term futures – Far-term futures) / Near-term futures
= ($104 – $100) / $104 = 3.85%
(Positive because market is in backwardation: near > far)

Step 3: Collateral Return
= Risk-free rate × (period / 12)
= 3% × (4/12) = 1.00%

Step 4: Total Return
= 5.00% + 3.85% + 1.00% = 9.85%

Trap answers:
• A (5.00%): Price return only, forgot roll and collateral
• C (8.85%): Forgot collateral return
• D (6.00%): Price + collateral, forgot roll return
keyFormulas: Price Return = (Current – Previous) / Previous
Roll Return = (Near – Far) / Near
Collateral Return = Rf × (months/12)
Total = Price + Roll + Collateral
questions.yourMistake: Forgot one of the three components (likely roll return or collateral return)

questions.title: Performance Presentation - Terminated Accounts
questions.question: Diana Brown (CFA) is preparing composite performance that includes accounts terminated during the year. What is REQUIRED for compliance with Standard III(D)?
questions.explanation:
Standard III(D) Performance Presentation:

Terminated accounts CAN be included, but you MUST disclose the termination DATES.

Omitting dates = VIOLATION (even if returns are included). Dates matter because viewers need to understand when/why accounts left the composite.

questions.title: Fair Dealing - IPO Allocation
questions.question: Brown's firm receives a hot IPO allocation. To comply with Standard III(B) Fair Dealing, shares should be allocated to:
questions.explanation:
Standard III(B) Fair Dealing — IPO Allocation:

Must allocate pro-rata to ALL suitable accounts:
✓ Discretionary accounts
✓ Non-discretionary accounts (if prior interest indicated)
✓ Family accounts
✓ Non-family accounts

Excluding any category = VIOLATION. 'Non-discretionary' doesn't mean 'exclude from fair treatment.'
questions.yourMistake: Thought certain account types could be excluded

questions.title: Priority of Transactions
questions.question: Denton (CFA) recommends Bio13 to client Hunter. Hunter asks Denton to delay purchasing shares for 30 days until his bonus arrives. Denton immediately buys Bio13 in his personal account, causing a temporary price increase. Did Denton violate Standard VI(B)?
questions.explanation:
NO violation because:

1. Hunter EXPLICITLY requested the delay — no pending client order existed
2. Front-running requires trading ahead of a pending order — Hunter voluntarily chose not to trade
3. No client disadvantage — 30 days later, price determined by market factors
4. Bio13 not suitable for other clients

Key: Client voluntarily delayed. Denton didn't 'trade ahead' because there was no order to trade ahead of.
questions.yourMistake: Thought any personal purchase before client = violation, but client explicitly requested delay

questions.title: Target Payout Adjustment Model
questions.question:
An analyst uses the target payout adjustment model to forecast dividends.

Given:
• Previous dividend: $2.00
• Expected EPS: $5.00
• Target payout ratio: 50%
• Company adjusts dividends over 4 years

The expected dividend for Year 1 is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate adjustment factor
Adjustment factor = 1 / years to adjust = 1/4 = 0.25

Step 2: Calculate target dividend
Target dividend = EPS × Target payout = $5.00 × 50% = $2.50

Step 3: Calculate gap from target
Gap = Target dividend – Previous dividend = $2.50 – $2.00 = $0.50

Step 4: Calculate expected dividend increase
Increase = Gap × Adjustment factor = $0.50 × 0.25 = $0.125

Step 5: Calculate new dividend
Year 1 dividend = Previous dividend + Increase = $2.00 + $0.125 = $2.125

Trap answers:
• B ($2.50): Jumped straight to target, forgot gradual adjustment
• C ($2.00): No change calculated
• D ($0.125): This is the increase, not the new dividend
keyFormulas: Adjustment factor = 1/n (years to adjust)
Increase = (EPS × Target – Prev Div) × Adj Factor
New Div = Prev Div + Increase
questions.yourMistake: Either jumped to target immediately or calculated increase but forgot to add to previous dividend

questions.title: Currency Swap Fixed Rate
questions.question: A 2-year currency swap has annual payments. The present value factors for the domestic currency are: PV₁ = 0.9610 (Year 1) and PV₂ = 0.9070 (Year 2). The annual fixed rate on this swap is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Fixed Rate = (1 - PV_final) / Σ(PV factors)

Step 1: Identify PV of final payment
PV_final = PV₂ = 0.9070

Step 2: Sum all PV factors
Σ(PV factors) = 0.9610 + 0.9070 = 1.8680

Step 3: Calculate fixed rate
Fixed Rate = (1 - 0.9070) / 1.8680 = 0.0930 / 1.8680 = 0.04978 ≈ 4.98%

Since payments are annual, no additional annualization needed.
If payments were semi-annual, multiply by 2.
keyFormulas: Fixed Rate = (1 - PV_final) / Σ(PV factors)
Annualize by multiplying by payment frequency

questions.title: Putable Bond Effective Convexity
questions.question: A putable bond can be put at par at the end of Year 1. The effective convexity of this bond:

choices.text: Will become negative if rates fall below the coupon
Will become negative if rates rise above the coupon

questions.explanation:
Putable vs Callable Convexity:

• Option-free bond: Always positive convexity
• Callable bond: CAN become negative (call limits upside when rates fall)
• Putable bond: CANNOT be negative (put provides floor, preserves upside)

The put option provides downside protection without limiting upside = always positive convexity.
keyFormulas: Callable → Can have negative convexity
Putable → Always positive convexity
questions.yourMistake: Confused putable with callable bond convexity behavior

questions.title: OAS and Interest Rate Volatility
questions.question: A callable bond has OAS of 51 bps. If bond price stays unchanged but interest rate volatility increases from 20% to 25%, the OAS will:
questions.explanation:
Z-Spread = OAS + Option Cost

For callable bond when volatility increases:
• Higher volatility → Higher option value → Higher option cost
• If price unchanged, Z-spread unchanged
• OAS = Z-spread - Option Cost
• Option Cost ↑ means OAS ↓

Example: Z-spread stays 100 bps, option cost goes from 49 to 60 bps → OAS drops from 51 to 40 bps.
keyFormulas: Z-Spread = OAS + Option Cost
↑ Volatility → ↑ Option Cost → ↓ OAS
questions.yourMistake: Thought higher volatility would increase OAS

questions.title: Capped Floating Rate Bond
questions.question: A floating rate bond pays the 1-year reference rate, capped at 5.0%. If interest rates can exceed 5% at some nodes in the tree, the bond's value is:
questions.explanation:
Uncapped Floater:
• Pays the full reference rate at each reset date
• Bondholders receive whatever the current rate is
• Value always equals par at reset dates because coupon adjusts fully to market rates

Capped Floater (5% cap in this case):
• Has a maximum coupon rate of 5%
• When market rates exceed 5%, bondholder only receives 5% instead of actual higher rate
• This creates a loss of interest income relative to an uncapped floater

Why it's worth less than par:
At nodes where interest rates can exceed the 5% cap:
1. Lost interest income: If reference rate is 7%, bondholder receives only 5% instead of 7%
2. This reduces the bond's value below par because cash flows are now lower than what would be received from an uncapped floater
3. The cap essentially hurts the bondholder = it's a benefit to the issuer but a cost to the investor

Key insight: The cap is like selling a call option on interest rates to the issuer.
keyFormulas: Uncapped floater = par at reset
Capped floater < par when rates can exceed cap
Cap benefit to issuer = cost to bondholder
questions.yourMistake: Treated capped floater like uncapped - forgot that the cap limits upside for bondholder when rates rise

questions.title: Bond Forward Rate Forecast
questions.question: Li forecasts that in 3 years, the 2-year spot rate will equal the current 2-year spot rate (2.20%), but lower than the implied forward rate. Given this forecast, a 5-year zero-coupon bond today is:
questions.explanation:
If Li forecasts future spot rate < implied forward rate:
• Current pricing uses implied forwards (higher rates)
• Actual future discounting will use lower rates
• Bond's actual future value > currently priced value
• Today's price is too LOW = UNDERVALUED

Fairly valued only if future spots = implied forwards.
keyFormulas: Future spot < implied forward → Bond undervalued
Future spot > implied forward → Bond overvalued
questions.yourMistake: Thought unchanged rate meant fairly valued

questions.title: CDS Upfront Premium
questions.question: CDS data: Credit spread = 4.0%, Duration = 4.5 years, Fixed coupon = 5.0%, Notional = $5M. The upfront premium received by the protection BUYER is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Upfront Premium = (Credit Spread - Fixed Coupon) × Duration × Notional
= (4.0% - 5.0%) × 4.5 × $5M
= -1.0% × 4.5 × $5M = -$225,000

Negative = protection SELLER pays to protection BUYER
(Because fixed coupon > spread, buyer will overpay through running payments)

Key: Use DURATION (4.5), not maturity!
keyFormulas: Upfront = (Spread - Coupon) × Duration × Notional
Use CDS duration, not maturity
questions.yourMistake: Used maturity instead of duration in calculation

questions.title: Temporal Method Ratio Analysis
questions.question: Under temporal method with average rate = 14,700 and current rate = 14,000. Which ratio remains UNCHANGED after translation?
questions.explanation:
Temporal Method Rates:
• Sales → Average rate (14,700)
• COGS → Historical/average when inventory purchased (14,700)

COGS/Sales: Both use same rate (14,700) → UNCHANGED

questions.title: Valuation Model Selection
questions.question: Firm A has stable dividend payout but plans expansion requiring dividends to exceed FCFE. It also has lower quality accounting disclosure. Most appropriate model:
questions.explanation:
Model Selection Framework:

Dividend Discount Model (DDM):
• Use when: Dividends bear a consistent relationship to company's profitability
• Use when: Company has stable dividend policy that reflects earnings capacity
• Don't use when: Dividends significantly differ from FCFE (like during expansion)

Residual Income Model:
• Use when: Company has high quality, transparent accounting disclosure
• Use when: Dividends are not paid or are unpredictable
• Don't use when: Accounting quality is questionable or aggressive

Free Cash Flow Models (FCFE/FCFF):
• Use when: Dividends significantly differ from FCFE
• Use when: Company is undergoing major capital structure changes
• Captures true cash-generating ability regardless of dividend policy

Applying to Firm A:
• Dividends > FCFE (expansion funded by borrowing or equity) → DDM inappropriate because dividends don't reflect sustainable cash generation
• Lower quality accounting disclosure → Residual income inappropriate because it relies on clean accounting numbers
• Free cash flow model is most appropriate - captures actual cash flows regardless of dividend policy or accounting choices
keyFormulas: DDM: Stable dividends = f(profitability)
RI: Requires quality accounting
FCF: Use when Div ≠ FCFE
questions.yourMistake: Chose DDM based on stable payout history, ignoring that planned expansion means dividends will exceed FCFE

questions.title: DDM Valuation with Threshold
questions.question: Using DDM: Required return = 8%, Payout = 40%, Year 3 price = $21.50, EPS forecasts = $1.27, $1.62, $1.91. Current price = $19.00. Policy considers stock fairly valued if within 2% of fair value. Stock is:
keyFormulas: DDM: V = Σ D/(1+r)^t + P_T/(1+r)^T
Check against threshold before concluding over/under

questions.title: FCFF vs FCFE Model Selection
questions.question: Firm plans aggressive debt-financed growth with highly fluctuating net borrowing. Growth will decline from 25-35% to 2%. Most appropriate model:
questions.explanation:
Two considerations:

1. Number of stages: High growth → Declining → Stable = THREE stages

2. FCFF vs FCFE:
• Fluctuating net borrowing = changing leverage
• FCFE unreliable with volatile debt
• FCFF better when capital structure changing

Answer: Three-stage FCFF
keyFormulas: Changing leverage → Use FCFF not FCFE
Multiple growth phases → Multi-stage model
questions.yourMistake: Chose FCFE despite fluctuating leverage

questions.title: FRA No-Arbitrage Rate
questions.question: A corporate treasurer expects to borrow $10 million in 1 month for a period of 6 months. To hedge the interest rate risk, she enters a 1×7 FRA. Current LIBOR rates are: 1-month = 0.60% and 7-month = 0.87%. Using a 30/360 day count convention, the annualized no-arbitrage fixed rate on this FRA is closest to:
questions.explanation:
A 1×7 FRA locks in a 6-month borrowing rate starting in 1 month.

'1×7' means: starts in 1 month, ends in 7 months → loan period = 6 months (180 days)

Formula:
FRA = {[1 + L₇×(210/360)] / [1 + L₁×(30/360)] - 1} × (360/180)

Step 1: Calculate the longer-term factor
1 + 0.0087 × (210/360) = 1 + 0.005075 = 1.005075

Step 2: Calculate the shorter-term factor
1 + 0.0060 × (30/360) = 1 + 0.000167 = 1.000167

Step 3: Compute the FRA rate
FRA = (1.005075 / 1.000167 - 1) × (360/180)
= (1.004907 - 1) × 2
= 0.004907 × 2 = 0.9814% ≈ 0.91%

Key: Use the 7-month rate (not 6-month) because the FRA ends at month 7.
keyFormulas: FRA rate = {[1 + L_long×(days_long/360)] / [1 + L_short×(days_short/360)] - 1} × (360/loan_days)
1×7 FRA uses 1-month and 7-month LIBOR rates
Loan period = end month - start month = 7 - 1 = 6 months
questions.yourMistake: Used 6-month rate instead of 7-month rate

questions.title: Reverse Carry Arbitrage
questions.question: Forward price is BELOW fair value. To exploit arbitrage, in addition to buying forward, you should:

choices.text: Borrow and short sell the underlying
Short sell underlying and invest proceeds at risk-free rate

questions.explanation:
Forward price < Fair value (forward is 'cheap'):

1. Buy forward (lock in cheap purchase price)
2. Short sell underlying (it's 'expensive' relatively)
3. Invest proceeds at risk-free rate until settlement

This is REVERSE carry arbitrage.

If forward ABOVE fair value: Do opposite (borrow and buy underlying).
keyFormulas: Forward < Fair → Buy forward, short spot, invest
Forward > Fair → Sell forward, buy spot, borrow
questions.yourMistake: Confused with regular carry arbitrage (forward overpriced)

questions.title: Backtesting Rolling Windows
questions.question: Backtesting a 10-factor strategy with risk parity weighting and monthly rebalancing. The model requires:
questions.explanation:
Why TWO iterations needed:

1. Iteration 1: Construct factor portfolios
   - Rank stocks, form long/short portfolios

2. Iteration 2: Calculate risk parity weights

   - Compute risk parity weights

Both must use only historical data to avoid look-ahead bias.

questions.title: Annual Parametric VaR
questions.question: Strategy has monthly mean = 0.5%, monthly std dev = 7.1%. 5% VaR = 1.65 std dev below mean. Annual 5% VaR is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Annualize parameters FIRST
• Annual return = 12 × 0.5% = 6.0%
• Annual std dev = √12 × 7.1% = 24.6%

Step 2: Calculate VaR
• VaR = -[6.0% - 1.65 × 24.6%]
• = -[6.0% - 40.6%] = 34.6%

Must annualize parameters before calculating VaR, not calculate monthly VaR then annualize.
keyFormulas: Annual σ = Monthly σ × √12
Annual return = Monthly × 12
Annualize params first, then calc VaR
questions.yourMistake: Calculated monthly VaR without annualizing

questions.title: Maximum Drawdown
questions.question: An equity market-neutral strategy is benchmarked against cash. Which risk measure is most appropriate as a complement to VaR?
questions.explanation:
Risk Measure Selection:

• Relative VaR: Tracking error vs benchmark (useless with cash benchmark = zero volatility)
• Surplus at risk: For pension fund surplus
• Max drawdown: Worst peak-to-trough decline - key for absolute return strategies

For market-neutral strategy benchmarked to cash:
• Relative VaR = regular VaR (no additional info)
• Max drawdown captures downside risk for absolute return assessment

questions.title: Real Yields and GDP
questions.question:
Country A: Nominal GDP change = +50 bps, Inflation change = +10 bps.
Country B: Nominal GDP change = +65 bps, Inflation change = +30 bps.
Which should experience larger increase in real yields?
questions.explanation:
Real GDP Growth = Nominal GDP - Inflation

Country A: +50 - 10 = +40 bps real growth
Country B: +65 - 30 = +35 bps real growth

Country A has larger real GDP growth increase → larger real yield increase.

Don't be fooled by higher nominal GDP (Country B) - inflation matters!
keyFormulas: Real GDP = Nominal GDP - Inflation
Higher real GDP growth → Higher real yields

questions.title: Breakeven Inflation
questions.question: 2-year nominal bond yield = 3.0%, 2-year real yield = 1.0%. The expected 2-year average inflation is most likely:
questions.explanation:
Breakeven Inflation (BEI) = Nominal - Real = 3.0% - 1.0% = 2.0%

BUT: BEI ≠ Expected Inflation!

BEI = Expected Inflation + Inflation Risk Premium

Therefore:
Expected Inflation = BEI - Risk Premium
Expected Inflation < 2.0%

The nominal yield includes compensation for inflation uncertainty.
keyFormulas: BEI = Nominal yield - Real yield
BEI = Expected inflation + Risk premium
questions.yourMistake: Equated BEI with expected inflation

questions.title: Convergence Theory
questions.question: If human capital externalities are large enough to make the production function linear (no diminishing returns), this is most consistent with:
questions.explanation:
Convergence Theories:

• Absolute: Diminishing returns → All converge
• Conditional: Diminishing returns → Same parameters converge
• Non-convergence: Constant returns → Rich stay ahead

Large externalities from human capital:
→ Offsets diminishing returns
→ Linear/constant returns production function
→ No force pushing toward convergence
→ NON-CONVERGENCE
keyFormulas: Diminishing returns → Convergence possible
Constant returns → Non-convergence
questions.yourMistake: Thought absolute convergence applies regardless of returns

questions.title: Time Series Covariance Stationarity
questions.question: First-differenced time series has: constant mean, constant variance, and residual autocorrelations with no lag having |t-stat| > critical value. The series is:
questions.explanation:
Covariance Stationarity Requirements:
1. Mean is constant ✓
2. Variance is constant ✓
3. Covariance with itself is constant ✓ (residuals uncorrelated)

NOT a random walk: AR coefficients are significant (past values help predict)

NOT seasonality: Would show significant autocorrelation at lag 4 for quarterly data

All three conditions met = COVARIANCE STATIONARY
questions.yourMistake: Confused first-differenced stationary series with random walk

questions.title: AR Model Forecast on First Differences
questions.question: An analyst estimates an AR(2) model on the first differences of quarterly sales growth (SG): Δŷ_t = b₀ + b₁Δy_(t-1) + b₂Δy_(t-2), where Δy_t = SG_t - SG_(t-1). The estimated coefficients are: b₀ = 0.0024, b₁ = -0.2021, b₂ = -0.5272. Recent sales growth data: SG₅₀ = 18.9%, SG₄₉ = 2.0%, SG₄₈ = -11.5%. The forecasted sales growth for t = 51 is closest to:
questions.explanation:
The model is: Δŷ_t = b₀ + b₁Δy_(t-1) + b₂Δy_(t-2)

Step 1: Calculate first differences (CHANGES, not levels)
Δy₅₀ = SG₅₀ - SG₄₉ = 18.9% - 2.0% = 16.9%
Δy₄₉ = SG₄₉ - SG₄₈ = 2.0% - (-11.5%) = 13.5%

Step 2: Plug into the regression equation
Δŷ₅₁ = 0.0024 + (-0.2021)(0.169) + (-0.5272)(0.135)
= 0.24% - 3.42% - 7.12% = -10.3%

Step 3: Convert back to level
SG₅₁ = SG₅₀ + Δŷ₅₁ = 18.9% + (-10.3%) = 8.6%
keyFormulas: Δŷ_t = b₀ + b₁Δy_(t-1) + b₂Δy_(t-2)
First difference inputs: Δy_t = SG_t - SG_(t-1)
Final forecast = Current level + Forecasted change
questions.yourMistake: Used levels instead of changes in the AR formula

questions.title: ML Classification: Algorithm Selection for Non-Separable Data
questions.question: For classification where data is not linearly separable and you want to avoid overfitting, the most suitable algorithm is:
questions.explanation:
Algorithm Comparison:

• Non-linear SVM: Handles non-linearity but HIGH overfitting risk
• Unconstrained CART: Can perfectly fit → HIGH overfitting
• Soft margin SVM: Handles non-linearity + LOW overfitting (penalty for misclassification)

Soft margin adds penalty for misclassified observations, optimizing trade-off between margin width and classification error.
keyFormulas: Soft margin = Non-linearity handling + Overfitting prevention
Penalty parameter controls bias-variance tradeoff

questions.title: R-squared and Adjusted R-squared
questions.question: Model 2 has two variables. Model 3 adds a third variable with t-stat = 1.92 (critical value = 2.0). Compared to Model 2, Model 3 has:

choices.text: Lower R² and higher adjusted R²
Higher R² and lower adjusted R²
Higher R² and higher adjusted R²
Lower R² and lower adjusted R²

questions.explanation:
Key Rules:
1. Adding ANY variable → R² increases (or stays same)
2. If |t-stat| > 1.0 → Adjusted R² increases

Analysis:
• New variable t-stat = 1.92 > 1.0
• R² ↑ (always increases with more variables)
• Adjusted R² ↑ (because |t| > 1)

Note: Even though p > 0.05 (not significant at 5%), adjusted R² still increases because |t| > 1.
keyFormulas: |t| > 1.0 → Adj R² increases
Adding variable → R² always increases
questions.yourMistake: Thought insignificant variable would lower adjusted R²

questions.title: Liquid Alternatives vs Hedge Funds
questions.question: Investor wants: (1) Lower incentive fees than traditional HFs, (2) More frequent redemptions than traditional HFs. Do liquid alternatives meet these requirements?
questions.explanation:

Traditional HF: 2/20 fee, lockup periods

questions.title: Multi-Strategy vs Fund of Funds
questions.question: Compared to fund of funds, multi-strategy hedge funds most likely have:
questions.explanation:
Multi-Strategy vs Fund of Funds:

questions.title: Hedge Fund Strategy for Drawdown
questions.question: Pension plan wants to limit drawdowns when combined with stock/bond portfolio. Best hedge fund strategy:
questions.explanation:
Strategies with LOWEST Drawdowns When Combined:
✓ Global macro

Best for drawdown reduction

questions.title: Fair Dealing - Contrary Recommendation
questions.question: Client asks to BUY a stock. Portfolio manager knows firm just issued SELL recommendation. Manager executes without informing client. This is:

choices.text: Violation - should have disclosed contrary recommendation
Violation - should have refused the order

questions.explanation:
Standard III(B) Fair Dealing:

'If clients place orders contrary to a current recommendation, they should be advised of the changed recommendation before the order is accepted.'

Client wanted to BUY, firm recommends SELL → Contrary order
Manager should have informed client of the sell recommendation BEFORE executing.

Client's expertise doesn't excuse the requirement to disclose.
keyFormulas: Contrary order = Must disclose current recommendation
Inform BEFORE accepting order
questions.yourMistake: Assumed client expertise meant no disclosure needed

questions.title: ETF Holding Period Cost
questions.question: ETF data: Management fee = 0.50%, One-way commission = 0.10%, Bid-ask spread = 0.20%. Expected 1-year holding period cost is:
questions.explanation:
Holding Period Cost = Round-trip Trading Cost + Management Fee

Round-trip Trading Cost:
= (One-way commission × 2) + (½ × Bid-ask spread × 2)
= (0.10% × 2) + (0.10% × 2)
= 0.20% + 0.20% = 0.40%

Total = 0.40% + 0.50% = 0.90%

Note: Pay half spread on buy, half on sell = full spread for round trip.
keyFormulas: Round-trip = 2×commission + spread
Total cost = Trading + Management
questions.yourMistake: Used one-way commission instead of round-trip

questions.title: Key Rate Duration and Volatility
questions.question: Li uses 3.25% monthly std dev of 15-year bond yield to estimate annual volatility of 11.26%. He concludes higher key rate durations for longer-term rates lead to higher long-term annualized term structure volatility. Are his calculation and conclusion correct?

choices.text: No, only the annualized volatility estimate is correct
No, only the conclusion about key rate duration is correct

questions.explanation:
Volatility Calculation:
Annual vol = Monthly vol × √12 = 3.25% × 3.464 = 11.26% ✓ CORRECT

Key Rate Duration Conclusion: INCORRECT
• Long-term securities DO have higher key rate durations
• BUT short-term rates are MORE VOLATILE than long-term rates
• Key rate duration measures price sensitivity, NOT rate volatility

He confused duration sensitivity with rate volatility.
keyFormulas: Annual σ = Monthly σ × √12
Short-term rates are more volatile than long-term rates
questions.yourMistake: Accepted the conclusion without checking that short-term rates are actually more volatile

questions.title: Economic Growth Components
questions.question:
Which statement about economic growth is CORRECT?

1. R&D spending leads to positive short-run growth
2. TFP = Capital deepening + Labor productivity
3. Investment impact depends on existing capital stock
questions.explanation:
Statement 1: WRONG
• R&D may cause SHORT-TERM disruption (creative destruction)
• Benefits come in LONG-RUN

Statement 2: WRONG - Formula is backwards!
• Correct: Labor Productivity = Capital Deepening + TFP
• TFP is a RESIDUAL, not a sum

Statement 3: CORRECT
• Low capital stock → Investment has LARGER impact
• Diminishing returns: First units of capital add more
keyFormulas: Labor Prod = Capital Deepening + TFP
Low K → Higher marginal product of capital

questions.title: Trade Opening - Neoclassical Model
questions.question:
Which is consistent with neoclassical model when trade opens?

1. Capital exporters grow above steady state
2. Developed countries run trade deficits
3. High K/L countries have lower investment returns
questions.explanation:
Statement 1: WRONG
• Capital outflows → Growth BELOW steady state (losing capital)

Statement 2: WRONG
• Capital exporters run SURPLUSES not deficits
• Capital outflow = Financial account deficit = Current account SURPLUS

Statement 3: CORRECT
• High K/L ratio → Diminishing marginal product of capital
• → Lower investment returns
keyFormulas: Capital export → Trade surplus
High K/L → Low MPK → Low returns
questions.yourMistake: Confused capital flows with trade balance direction

questions.title: Residual Plot - Heteroskedasticity
questions.question: Model: ROE ~ SALES. Residual plot shows variance increasing with SALES. Most appropriate conclusion:
questions.explanation:
Variance increasing with independent variable = CONDITIONAL heteroskedasticity

Effects:
• F-test becomes unreliable
• t-statistics biased
• More Type I errors

NOT unconditional heteroskedasticity:
• Unconditional = variance NOT correlated with X
• Here variance IS correlated with SALES → CONDITIONAL
keyFormulas: Variance varies with X → Conditional heteroskedasticity
Heteroskedasticity → F-test and t-tests unreliable
questions.yourMistake: Confused conditional (variance varies with X) with unconditional (variance unrelated to X)

questions.title: Additional Compensation - Non-Monetary Benefits
questions.question: Sarah Chen, CFA, is a portfolio manager at Ridgewood Capital. One of her clients, Apex Industries, is pleased with the fund's recent performance and offers Sarah a performance-based bonus of $25,000, payable quarterly. Sarah obtains written approval from both Apex and her employer, Ridgewood Capital, before accepting the arrangement. Separately, the CEO of Apex invites Sarah to use the company's luxury yacht for a weekend trip. Sarah accepts the yacht invitation without notifying Ridgewood, reasoning that it is a personal gift unrelated to her investment performance. Which of Sarah's actions most likely violates the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct?

choices.text: Neither the bonus arrangement nor the yacht usage violates the Standards
The bonus arrangement violates Standard IV(B) - Additional Compensation Arrangements
The yacht usage violates Standard IV(B) - Additional Compensation Arrangements
Both the bonus and yacht usage violate Standard IV(B)

questions.explanation:
Standard IV(B) - Additional Compensation Arrangements:

Bonus Arrangement: NO violation
• Sarah obtained written approval from both Apex (client) and Ridgewood (employer) ✓
• Performance-based compensation from clients is permitted when properly disclosed

Yacht Usage: VIOLATION of Standard IV(B)
• Standard IV(B) requires members to disclose to their employer ALL compensation/benefits received from clients or prospects
• A luxury yacht weekend is a valuable non-monetary benefit
• Creates a potential conflict — Sarah may favor Apex over other clients
• MUST be disclosed to and approved by employer regardless of whether it's 'performance-related'

Key takeaway: 'Unrelated to performance' is irrelevant — ANY benefit from a client that could create a conflict of interest must be disclosed to the employer.
keyFormulas: Standard IV(B): ALL compensation/benefits from clients must be disclosed to employer
Non-monetary gifts (yacht, travel, entertainment) are covered
The test is whether a conflict COULD arise, not whether the gift is performance-related
questions.yourMistake: Thought only monetary compensation needed disclosure

questions.title: Build-Up Approach - SCRP
questions.question: Estimate SCRP using build-up approach. Given: Cost of equity = 13.5%, ERP = 7.0%, Size premium = 1.2%, Risk-free rate = 3.0%. The SCRP is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Build-Up Approach:
r_e = r_f + ERP + Size Premium + SCRP

Solving for SCRP:
SCRP = r_e - (r_f + ERP + SP)
= 13.5% - (3.0% + 7.0% + 1.2%)
= 13.5% - 11.2%
= 2.3%

Trap answers:
• 3.0% → Used CAPM formula with beta
• 3.5% → Forgot size premium
keyFormulas: Build-up: r_e = r_f + ERP + SP + SCRP
SCRP = r_e - (r_f + ERP + SP)
questions.yourMistake: Forgot to include size premium in the build-up components

questions.title: ABS Credit Analysis - Statistics-Based
questions.question: An ABS is backed by short-term credit card receivables. The pool is granular (many small receivables) and homogeneous. The most appropriate credit analysis approach is:
questions.explanation:
ABS Credit Analysis Approaches:

• Loan-by-loan: Small, heterogeneous pools (each loan unique)
• Portfolio-based: Medium-term, dynamic pools (composition changes)
• Statistics-based: Short-term, granular, homogeneous pools

Credit card ABS characteristics:
• Short-term ✓
• Granular (many small receivables) ✓
• Homogeneous ✓

→ Use aggregate statistics (mean default probability, recovery rate, variance)
keyFormulas: Short-term + Granular + Homogeneous → Statistics-based
Portfolio-based is for dynamic (changing) pools
questions.yourMistake: Chose portfolio-based, which is for dynamic pools that change over time

questions.title: Mundell-Fleming: Currency Appreciation
questions.question:
Janet Kuspa evaluates three countries with floating exchange rates using the Mundell-Fleming model. The countries have the following characteristics:

Country A: High capital mobility, Expansionary monetary policy, Restrictive fiscal policy
Country B: Low capital mobility, Expansionary monetary policy, Restrictive fiscal policy
Country C: Low capital mobility, Restrictive monetary policy, Restrictive fiscal policy

Based on the Mundell-Fleming model, which country is most likely to experience appreciation of its domestic currency in the short term?
questions.explanation:
Under the Mundell-Fleming model with FLOATING exchange rates:

Country A (High capital mobility):
• Expansionary monetary → C↓
• Restrictive fiscal → C↓
• Net: Currency depreciates

Country B (Low capital mobility):
• Expansionary monetary → C↓ (increases spending/imports)
• Restrictive fiscal → C↑ (decreases spending/imports)
• Net: INDETERMINATE (opposing effects)

Country C (Low capital mobility):
• Restrictive monetary → C↑ (reduces spending/imports)
• Restrictive fiscal → C↑ (reduces spending/imports)
• Net: Currency APPRECIATES

Key: With HIGH capital mobility, capital flows dominate (monetary policy has bigger impact through interest rates). With LOW capital mobility, trade flows dominate (focus on spending and imports).
keyFormulas: High capital mobility: Capital flows dominate → focus on interest rate effects
Low capital mobility: Trade flows dominate → focus on spending/import effects
Restrictive monetary + Restrictive fiscal (low mobility) = appreciation
questions.yourMistake: Selected Country A — forgot that with high capital mobility, expansionary monetary policy causes depreciation through capital outflows

questions.title: Normalizing Private Company Earnings
questions.question:
Margaret Smith is normalizing the operating income of Lytham Corporation, a small, family-owned company, to compare it with public companies. She notes the following:

1. The CEO's annual salary is $600,000. A similarly qualified CEO at a comparable public company earns $1,000,000.
2. Lytham owns a luxury apartment used by the CEO for business and personal travel. If Lytham were public, the apartment would be sold. Annual operating costs are $200,000 and annual depreciation expense is $200,000.
3. Lytham pays 15% of net income in dividends; Smith believes this would be 50% if Lytham were public.

The required adjustments to normalize Lytham's earnings will result in:

choices.text: A reduction in reported operating income
No change in reported operating income
An increase in reported operating income

questions.explanation:
Item 1 — CEO Salary: Increase SG&A by $400,000 ($1,000,000 – $600,000) to reflect market-rate compensation → Decreases operating income by $400,000.

Item 2 — Apartment: If sold, both operating costs ($200,000) and depreciation ($200,000) would be eliminated → Increases operating income by $400,000.

Item 3 — Dividends: Dividends are NOT a component of operating income, so changing the payout ratio has NO effect on operating income.

Net impact: –$400,000 + $400,000 + $0 = $0 (no change).

Key: Dividends are paid from net income, not operating income. Don't confuse dividend policy with operating adjustments.
keyFormulas: CEO salary normalization: Increase SG&A to market rate
Remove personal-use assets: Eliminate both operating costs AND depreciation
Dividends do NOT affect operating income
questions.yourMistake: Likely forgot that the apartment adjustment offsets the salary adjustment, or incorrectly included dividends as an operating item

questions.title: Equity Value with Control Premium and DLOM
questions.question:
Calcyte is a publicly traded company with an equity value of $9,043 million. Margaret Smith conducts a valuation for a private buyout client interested in purchasing a controlling stake. She determines the relevant discount for lack of control (DLOC) to be 23% and the relevant discount for lack of marketability (DLOM) to be 20%.

After applying the appropriate discounts or premiums, the value of Calcyte's equity (in $ millions) to the private buyout client should be closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Convert DLOC to a Control Premium
DLOC = 1 – [1/(1 + Control Premium)]
Control Premium = [1/(1 – DLOC)] – 1
Control Premium = [1/(1 – 0.23)] – 1 = 1/0.77 – 1 = 0.2987 or 29.87%

Step 2: Apply Control Premium (add, since buyer gains control)
Step 3: Apply DLOM (subtract, since firm will be private post-buyout)

Value = $9,043 × (1 + 0.2987) × (1 – 0.20)
Value = $9,043 × 1.2987 × 0.80
Value ≈ $9,395 million

Common mistakes:
• A ($8,898): Using DLOC directly as control premium → $9,043 × 1.23 × 0.80
• C ($11,744): Forgetting to apply DLOM → $9,043 × 1.2987
keyFormulas: Control Premium = [1/(1 – DLOC)] – 1
Value = Public Equity × (1 + Control Premium) × (1 – DLOM)
DLOC ≠ Control Premium — must convert!

questions.title: Equity Method: Carrying Value with Excess Purchase Price
questions.question:
On 1 January, RMRL purchased a 30% interest in Begonia Bus Inc.'s outstanding common equity for $12,000,000. The excess purchase price was $2,150,000. Half of the excess was attributable to Begonia's plant and equipment (straight-line depreciation, 10-year remaining useful life, zero residual value), and the other half was attributable to land. RMRL has significant influence over Begonia. Begonia is expected to report net income of $1,500,000 for the current year and not pay any dividends.

The estimated carrying value of RMRL's investment in Begonia at the end of the current year should be:
questions.explanation:
Under the equity method:

Step 1: RMRL's share of Begonia's net income
30% × $1,500,000 = $450,000

Step 2: Amortize excess purchase price for plant and equipment
Excess for P&E = 0.5 × $2,150,000 = $1,075,000
Annual amortization = $1,075,000 / 10 years = $107,500
(Land is NOT amortized)

Step 3: Calculate carrying value
= Purchase price + Share of NI – Amortization of excess
= $12,000,000 + $450,000 – $107,500
= $12,342,500

Common mistakes:
• B ($12,450,000): Forgot to amortize the excess purchase price for P&E
• C ($13,392,500): Used 100% of Begonia's NI instead of 30%
keyFormulas: Equity method: Carrying value = Cost + Share of NI – Dividends – Amortization of excess
Only amortize excess on depreciable assets (P&E), NOT land
Use investor's share (30%) of NI, not 100%
questions.yourMistake: Common error: forgetting to amortize excess purchase price or using 100% of NI

questions.title: Accruals Ratios: BS-Based vs CF-Based Trends
questions.question:
Ahmad reviews the trend in RMRL's accruals ratios over the past two years:

                          Most Recent Year    Year Ago
BS-based accruals ratio      4.3%              0.6%
CF-based accruals ratio      1.7%             –2.5%
Beneish M-score             –1.94             –1.43
Altman Z-score               1.54              1.85

With respect to RMRL's accruals ratios, Ahmad should conclude that:

choices.text: Both the balance-sheet-based and cash-flow-based accruals ratios have improved
The BS-based accruals ratio has deteriorated, but the CF-based accruals ratio has improved
The BS-based accruals ratio has improved, but the CF-based accruals ratio has deteriorated

questions.explanation:
For accruals ratios, use ABSOLUTE VALUES — closer to zero = better quality.

BS-based accruals ratio:
• Year Ago: |0.6%| = 0.6%
• Most Recent: |4.3%| = 4.3%
• Absolute value INCREASED → DETERIORATED

CF-based accruals ratio:
• Year Ago: |–2.5%| = 2.5%
• Most Recent: |1.7%| = 1.7%
• Absolute value DECREASED → IMPROVED

Key insight: The sign doesn't matter for accruals ratios — it's the magnitude (absolute value) that indicates earnings quality. Lower absolute values mean less accrual-based earnings, which is higher quality.
keyFormulas: Accruals ratios: Use ABSOLUTE VALUE to assess
Lower |accruals ratio| = higher earnings quality = improvement
Higher |accruals ratio| = lower earnings quality = deterioration
questions.yourMistake: Likely looked at the direction of the numbers rather than comparing absolute values

questions.title: FSA: Pension Plan Service Cost Recognition
questions.question:
Anita Daani analyzes KTR Insurance, which reports under IFRS. KTR has a defined benefit pension plan (Plan A). For the most recent year, Plan A had a current service cost of $10 million and a past service cost of $2 million.

For the most recent year, KTR's operating expense (in $ millions) related to Plan A was:
questions.explanation:
Under IFRS, service cost has TWO sub-components:
1. Current service cost: $10 million
2. Past service cost: $2 million

BOTH are recognized as operating expense on the income statement.
Operating expense = $10 + $2 = $12 million

Key distinction — IFRS vs US GAAP:
• IFRS: Past service costs go to P&L immediately as operating expense
• US GAAP: Past service costs go to OCI first, then amortized to P&L over average service lives

If this were US GAAP, the answer would be $10 million (current service cost only).

Wrong answers:
• A ($8): Subtracted past service cost instead of adding
• B ($10): Only included current service cost (US GAAP treatment)
keyFormulas: IFRS: Operating expense = Current service cost + Past service cost
US GAAP: Operating expense = Current service cost only (past service cost → OCI)
This is a common IFRS vs GAAP trap question
questions.yourMistake: Used US GAAP treatment (only current service cost) instead of IFRS treatment (both current + past)

questions.title: Treasury Stock Method: Diluted Shares with RSUs
questions.question:
Daani assesses the dilutive effect of KTR's restricted stock units (RSUs) using the treasury stock method and the following data:

Basic shares outstanding at end of year: 2,700 million
Number of unvested RSUs at end of year: 150 million
Average unrecognized share-based compensation expense: $840 million
Average share price during the most recent year: $7

Using the treasury stock method, KTR's number of diluted shares outstanding at the end of the most recent year (in millions) is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Treasury stock method for RSUs:

Step 1: Start with basic shares = 2,700 million

Step 2: Add unvested RSUs = +150 million

Step 3: Subtract assumed repurchases
= Average unrecognized compensation / Average share price
= $840 million / $7 = 120 million

Diluted shares = 2,700 + 150 – 120 = 2,730 million

The logic: The unrecognized compensation expense represents proceeds the company would theoretically receive. These proceeds are used to 'repurchase' shares at the average market price, reducing the dilutive impact.

Common mistakes:
• B (2,850): Forgot to subtract assumed repurchases
• C (2,970): Added assumed repurchases instead of subtracting
keyFormulas: Diluted shares = Basic + RSUs – (Unrecognized comp expense / Avg share price)
Treasury stock method: Net dilution, not gross dilution
Assumed repurchases reduce the dilutive impact

questions.title: Binomial Tree Calibration: Adjusting Forward Rates
questions.question:
Susanne Blythe is calibrating a binomial interest rate tree to price a default-free 3-year bond with a 3.5% annual coupon priced at par ($100). Interest rate volatility is 10% and branching from each node to a high or low state occurs with equal probability (0.5). The 1-year forward rates at Year 0 and Year 1 are confirmed correct. She needs to determine whether the Year 2 rates require adjustment.

The binomial tree rates are:

Year 0: 2.4500%
Year 1: 3.8784% (up), 3.1754% (down)
Year 2: 5.3534% (up-up), 4.3830% (up-down), 3.5885% (down-down)

Using backward induction, calculate the bond's value at Year 0. Based on your result, in the next calibration iteration Blythe should:

choices.text: Decrease the 1-year forward rates at Year 2 (calculated value is below $100)
Leave the 1-year forward rates at Year 2 unchanged (calculated value equals $100)
Increase the 1-year forward rates at Year 2 (calculated value is above $100)

questions.explanation:
Backward induction from Year 3 to Year 0:

Step 1: Year 3 cash flow at all terminal nodes = coupon + par = $103.50

Step 2: Discount back to Year 2 nodes
Node UU: 103.50 / 1.053534 = $98.2408
Node UD: 103.50 / 1.043830 = $99.1541
Node DD: 103.50 / 1.035885 = $99.9146

Step 3: Year 1 node values (add coupon, take probability-weighted average, discount)
Node U: [3.5 + 0.5(98.2408) + 0.5(99.1541)] / 1.038784
= [3.5 + 98.6975] / 1.038784 = $98.3818
Node D: [3.5 + 0.5(99.1541) + 0.5(99.9146)] / 1.031754
= [3.5 + 99.5344] / 1.031754 = $99.8633

Step 4: Year 0 value
[3.5 + 0.5(98.3818) + 0.5(99.8633)] / 1.024500
= [3.5 + 99.1226] / 1.024500 = $100.1684

Result: $100.1684 > $100.00 (market price)
The model overvalues the bond → Forward rates at Year 2 must be INCREASED to lower the calculated value.
keyFormulas: Backward induction: Value = [Coupon + 0.5(V_up) + 0.5(V_down)] / (1 + rate)
At terminal nodes: Cash flow = Coupon + Par
Calculated > Market → Increase rates; Calculated < Market → Decrease rates
questions.yourMistake: May have confused the direction — if bond value is too high, rates need to go UP (inverse relationship)

questions.title: Negative Convexity: Callable vs Putable Bonds
questions.question:
Blythe evaluates three bonds issued by Y Corporation, all with 3-year maturity and 4.5% annual coupon:

Bond 1: Option-free bond
Bond 2: Putable at 100, one year and two years from now
Bond 3: Callable at 102, one year and two years from now

Which of the bonds issued by Y Corporation is most likely to exhibit negative convexity?
questions.explanation:
Bond 3 (the callable bond) is most likely to exhibit negative convexity.

When rates are HIGH: The call option is far out-of-the-money, so the callable bond behaves like a straight bond with positive convexity.

When rates are LOW: The call option is near or in-the-money, and the bond's price is capped near the call price. This creates negative convexity — the upside is limited while the downside remains.

Negative convexity means: Price gains from rate decreases are SMALLER than price losses from equivalent rate increases.

Bond 1 (option-free): Always has positive convexity.
Bond 2 (putable): Always has positive convexity — the put provides a floor that enhances convexity.
Bond 3 (callable): Exhibits negative convexity when the call is near the money.

Memory aid: Callable = Capped upside = negative Convexity. Putable = Protected downside = Positive convexity.
keyFormulas: Callable bonds: negative convexity when call is near the money
Putable bonds: ALWAYS positive convexity
Option-free bonds: ALWAYS positive convexity
questions.yourMistake: May have confused which embedded option creates negative convexity

questions.title: Implied Interest Cost of a Lease
questions.question:
Sebastian Traver at Feldcroft Inc. evaluates a 10-year helicopter lease with the following terms:
• Monthly payments of $125,000 at the end of each month
• Fair value of helicopter: $15,000,000
• Direct cost incurred by Feldcroft at lease inception: $750,000
• Residual value at end of lease: $8,700,000
• Feldcroft's unsecured incremental borrowing rate: 8%

The implied annual interest cost of the helicopter lease is closest to:
questions.explanation:
The implied interest cost equates the initial cash outflow to the PV of future cash flows.

Using a financial calculator:
PV = –$15,750,000 (fair value $15M + direct costs $750K)
PMT = $125,000
N = 120 (10 years × 12 months)
FV = $8,700,000
Solve for i = 0.5249% per month

Implied annual rate = 0.5249% × 12 = 6.299% ≈ 6.30%

Common mistakes:
• B (7.10%): Excluded the $750,000 direct cost from PV → PV = –$15,000,000
• C (8.00%): Used Feldcroft's incremental borrowing rate instead of calculating the implied rate from the lease cash flows

Key: The implied interest cost is derived from the ACTUAL lease cash flows, not from the borrowing rate. Direct costs must be included in the initial outflow.
keyFormulas: PV = Fair value + Direct costs (total initial outflow)
Solve for monthly rate, then annualize: annual rate = monthly rate × 12
Implied lease rate ≠ incremental borrowing rate
questions.yourMistake: Either excluded direct costs or used the borrowing rate instead of solving for the implied rate

questions.title: Country Spread Model: Equity Risk Premium
questions.question:
Feldcroft has operations in Country A, an emerging market representing 10% of the company's revenue. Traver uses the country spread model (no adjustment for relative volatility) with the following data:

• Current US equity risk premium: 5.94%
• 10-year US Treasury bond yield: 3.50%
• Country A 10-year bond yield (local currency): 7.55%
• Country A 10-year bond yield (denominated in USD): 5.15%

Based on the country spread model, the equity risk premium that should be used in calculating Feldcroft's cost of equity is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Country Spread Model:
ERP = ERP_developed + (λ × Country Risk Premium)

Step 1: Calculate Country Risk Premium
CRP = Yield on Country A bond (in USD) – Yield on US Treasury
CRP = 5.15% – 3.50% = 1.65%

IMPORTANT: Use the USD-denominated bond (5.15%), NOT the local currency bond (7.55%). The local currency bond includes FX risk, which is not a credit spread.

Step 2: Apply exposure weighting
λ = 10% (Feldcroft's revenue exposure to Country A)

Step 3: Calculate ERP
ERP = 5.94% + (0.10 × 1.65%) = 5.94% + 0.165% = 6.105% ≈ 6.11%

Common mistakes:
• B (6.35%): Used local currency bond yield (7.55%) instead of USD-denominated (5.15%)
• C (7.59%): Did not apply λ weighting → 5.94% + 1.65% = 7.59%
keyFormulas: ERP = ERP_developed + (λ × CRP)
CRP = EM bond yield (USD-denominated) – US Treasury yield
Use USD-denominated EM bond, NOT local currency bond
λ = proportion of revenue from the emerging market
questions.yourMistake: Either used the local currency bond or forgot to weight by λ

questions.title: Pro Forma Income Statement: Acquisition Adjustments
questions.question:
Traver prepares a pro forma income statement for Feldcroft's acquisition of a target company. The acquisition will be funded with new debt (including refinancing the target's existing debt). He generates cost synergies. After separating D&A from operating expenses, Traver models the following adjustments:

• Interest expense: Add interest from new debt issuance to the target's current interest expense
• Operating expenses: Add cost synergies to, and subtract cost dis-synergies from, combined operating expenses
• D&A expense: Add amortization of acquired intangible assets to combined D&A

Which of the following balances does Traver most likely model correctly?
questions.explanation:
C is correct — D&A is modeled correctly:
1. Combine acquirer and target D&A ✓
2. Add amortization of acquired intangible assets ✓

A is INCORRECT — Interest expense has errors:
• Traver adds new debt interest to the TARGET's current interest expense
• But the target's debt is being REFINANCED as part of the new debt issuance
• This double-counts the target's pre-acquisition interest expense
• Correct approach: Start with acquirer's interest expense, then add interest on ALL new debt (which already includes refinanced target debt)

B is INCORRECT — Operating expenses have the direction reversed:
• Traver ADDS cost synergies and SUBTRACTS dis-synergies
• This is backwards! Cost synergies are SAVINGS → should REDUCE (subtract from) operating expenses
• Cost dis-synergies are extra costs → should INCREASE (add to) operating expenses
• Correct: Subtract synergies, add dis-synergies
keyFormulas: Pro forma D&A = Combined D&A + Amortization of acquired intangibles
Pro forma OpEx = Combined OpEx – Cost synergies + Dis-synergies
Pro forma Interest = Acquirer interest + Interest on ALL new debt (don't double count target)
questions.yourMistake: May have missed the double-counting of interest or the reversed direction of synergies

questions.title: ML Overfitting: Bias-Variance Tradeoff
questions.question:
Megan Helmer uses machine learning to build a model that categorizes companies by whether their predicted ROE is low or high. The model uses multiple features to explain variations in ROE. The model produces low error rates using training data, but much higher error rates using out-of-sample data.

Helmer's ROE prediction model most likely suffers from:
questions.explanation:
The model has LOW in-sample error but HIGH out-of-sample error → Classic sign of OVERFITTING.

Bias-Variance Tradeoff:
• Bias error (underfitting): Model is too simple, poor fit on BOTH training and test data. High in-sample error.
• Variance error (overfitting): Model is too complex, fits noise in training data. Low in-sample error but high out-of-sample error.
• Base error: Irreducible randomness in the data. Affects both training and test data equally.

Here:
• Low training error → Model fits training data well → NOT underfitting, NOT bias error
• High out-of-sample error → Model doesn't generalize → Overfitting with variance error

The model has learned the noise/idiosyncrasies of the training data rather than the true underlying patterns.
keyFormulas: Low in-sample + High out-of-sample = Overfitting + Variance error
High in-sample + High out-of-sample = Underfitting + Bias error
Base error = irreducible noise (affects both)
questions.yourMistake: May have confused base error (random noise) with variance error (poor generalization from overfitting)

questions.title: Logistic Regression: Probability of Default
questions.question:
Helmer builds a logistic regression model to predict the 1-year probability of default for junk bond issuers using two independent variables: the ratio of debt to total capital (LEVERAGE) and the interest coverage ratio (COVERAGE). The estimated coefficients are:

Intercept: –20.0
LEVERAGE: 65.5
COVERAGE: –35.0

ACME is an issuer with LEVERAGE of 0.8 and COVERAGE of 0.9. Based on the logistic regression model, the probability that ACME defaults within the next year is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate the linear combination
b₀ + b₁×LEVERAGE + b₂×COVERAGE
= –20.0 + 65.5(0.8) + (–35.0)(0.9)
= –20.0 + 52.4 – 31.5
= 0.9

Step 2: Apply the logistic function
P = 1 / (1 + e^(–z)), where z = 0.9
P = 1 / (1 + e^(–0.9))
P = 1 / (1 + 0.4066)
P = 1 / 1.4066
P = 0.7109 ≈ 71%

Common mistakes:
• A (29%): Forgot the negative sign → P = 1/(1 + e^(+0.9)) = 1/3.46 = 29%
• C (90%): Treated as linear regression → P = 0.9 = 90% (didn't apply logistic transform)

Key: The logistic function is P = 1/(1 + e^(–z)), note the NEGATIVE sign in the exponent.
keyFormulas: Logistic: P = 1/(1 + e^(–z)) where z = b₀ + b₁X₁ + b₂X₂
Note the NEGATIVE sign: e^(–z), not e^(+z)
Linear combination first, THEN apply logistic transform
questions.yourMistake: Either forgot the negative sign in e^(–z) or didn't apply the logistic transform at all

questions.title: Regression Assumption Violations: Corrective Action
questions.question:
Helmer builds a linear regression model for manufacturing companies:

Model 1: MARGIN_t = b₀ + b₁×INPUT_t + b₂×LOGISTICS_t + ε_t

where MARGIN is profit margin, INPUT is raw material cost inflation, and LOGISTICS is freight cost inflation. She uses five years of quarterly data for 100 companies.

She makes two observations:
• Observation 1: Significant deviations of residuals from the diagonal in the Q-Q plot
• Observation 2: The null hypothesis of the Breusch-Pagan test is rejected

With respect to Observation 2, this indicates that:

choices.text: A larger sample size should be used
Robust standard errors should be calculated

questions.explanation:
The Breusch-Pagan test:
• H₀: No conditional heteroskedasticity (homoskedastic residuals)
• H₁: Conditional heteroskedasticity is present

Since H₀ is REJECTED → Conditional heteroskedasticity is present.

This means the variance of residuals is related to the independent variables, which:
• Biases the standard errors of coefficients
• Makes t-statistics and F-tests unreliable
• May lead to incorrect inference (too many Type I errors)

Correction: Use ROBUST STANDARD ERRORS (White's heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors), which adjust the standard errors to account for the heteroskedasticity.

Why not the other choices?
• A: Heteroskedasticity requires correction — can't ignore it
• B: Increasing sample size addresses multicollinearity, not heteroskedasticity
keyFormulas: Breusch-Pagan: H₀ = no conditional heteroskedasticity
Reject H₀ → heteroskedasticity present → use robust standard errors
Larger sample size fixes multicollinearity, NOT heteroskedasticity

questions.title: REIT Valuation: P/AFFO Disadvantage
questions.question:
Sarah Lambert researches REIT A, a hotel REIT. She notes that recent property market transaction volumes have been high. In addition, REIT A has recorded a number of one-time gains and charges.

Lambert considers the potential impact these issues could have on different valuation approaches. The issues Lambert is considering regarding REIT A would pose a disadvantage for which of the following valuation models?
questions.explanation:
P/AFFO is disadvantaged because one-time gains and accounting charges directly affect the income statement, making FFO and AFFO harder to compute and complicating comparisons between companies.

Why NOT the others?

• NAV (A): Actually BENEFITS from high transaction volumes — more property comparables make it easier to estimate net asset values. High transaction volumes = more market data = more reliable NAV.

• DDM (C): Not significantly affected. One-time charges have limited effect on dividend payouts since REITs pay dividends based on taxable income requirements, not accounting income. REITs distribute a high percentage of income by law, and one-time items don't usually change that.

Key: P/AFFO is income-statement-based, so anything that distorts the income statement (one-time items, gains, charges) directly impairs this metric.
keyFormulas: P/AFFO: Disadvantaged by one-time gains/charges (income statement distortion)
NAV: Advantaged by high transaction volumes (more comparables)
DDM: Relatively unaffected by one-time items (dividends are stable)
questions.yourMistake: May have thought NAV would be disadvantaged, but high transaction volumes actually help NAV estimation

questions.title: REIT B: Calculating P/AFFO Multiple
questions.question:
Lambert reviews REIT B, an industrial REIT, and calculates the P/AFFO multiple using the following data (in thousands):

Funds from operations (FFO): $465,419
(Gains)/Losses from sale of depreciable real estate: $22,613
Non-cash (straight-line) rent adjustment: $14,705
Recurring maintenance-type capex and leasing commissions: $33,297
Shares outstanding: 100,000
Current share price: $74.65

The P/AFFO multiple for REIT B is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Step 1: Calculate AFFO
AFFO = FFO – Non-cash rent adjustment – Recurring maintenance capex & leasing commissions
AFFO = $465,419 – $14,705 – $33,297 = $417,417

IMPORTANT: Do NOT subtract gains/losses from sale of depreciable real estate — those have ALREADY been removed when calculating FFO. Subtracting them again would double-count.

Step 2: Calculate AFFO per share
AFFO/share = $417,417 / 100,000 = $4.17

Step 3: Calculate P/AFFO
P/AFFO = $74.65 / $4.17 = 17.9x

Common mistakes:
• A (16.6x): Only subtracted non-cash rent, forgot maintenance capex
• C (18.9x): Also subtracted gains/losses (double-counting since already removed from FFO)
keyFormulas: AFFO = FFO – Non-cash rent adjustments – Recurring maintenance capex
Do NOT subtract gains/losses again (already excluded from FFO)
P/AFFO = Share price / AFFO per share
questions.yourMistake: Either forgot to subtract maintenance capex or double-counted gains already excluded from FFO

questions.title: BCT Compliance Manual: Independence and Objectivity
questions.question:
Irina Benoit, CFA, starts her own firm (BCT) and writes a compliance manual with three procedures:

Procedure 1: Analysts may accept gifts in the form of business-related entertainment to a maximum value listed by the compliance office.

Procedure 2: For all analysts, the purchase of a company's stock through a private placement is capped at a maximum per private placement as listed by the compliance office.

Procedure 3: When attending meetings at an issuer's headquarters, analysts are allowed to accept modest commercial transportation and hotel accommodation paid by the issuer.

Which procedure in the BCT compliance manual is NOT consistent with the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct?
questions.explanation:
Procedure 3 violates Standard I(B) Independence and Objectivity.

The recommended procedures for Standard I(B) explicitly state: When attending meetings at an issuer's headquarters, members and candidates should PAY FOR their own commercial transportation and hotel charges. No corporate issuer should reimburse members or candidates for air transportation.

Allowing issuers to pay for transportation and hotels creates a conflict of interest that compromises the analyst's independence and objectivity.

Procedure 1 is CONSISTENT: Standard I(B) permits customary, ordinary business-related entertainment as long as it doesn't influence or reward analysts. Setting a maximum value is a recommended practice.

Procedure 2 is CONSISTENT: Standard I(B) recommends formal policies with strict limits on employee purchases through private placements. Capping purchases is appropriate.
keyFormulas: Standard I(B): Analysts must pay their own transportation and hotel when visiting issuers
Business entertainment with value limits = acceptable
Private placement caps = acceptable
Issuer-paid travel/lodging = NOT acceptable
questions.yourMistake: May have thought one of the other procedures was inconsistent, but Procedures 1 and 2 follow recommended practices

questions.title: Multistage Residual Income Valuation
questions.question:
Victoria Lazslo values Firm A using a multistage residual income model. She compiles the following data:

| Item | Value |
|------|-------|
| Constant long-term growth rate | 9.6% |
| Constant long-term ROE | 16.0% |
| Market price per share | $220.00 |
| Book value per share | $166.00 |
| Cost of equity | 12.5% |
