questions.yourMistake: ADDED the CVA instead of SUBTRACTING it, then reversed the spread calculation. Wrong: PV_corp = 82.1927 + 2.924 = 85.1167, Yield = (100/85.1167)^0.2 - 1 = 3.2754%, Spread = 4.00% - 3.2754% = 0.72%.

questions.title: Monte Carlo Drift Adjustment
questions.question:
Alice Kent, a fixed-income analyst, wants to develop a more flexible model than the binomial tree. She uses the Monte Carlo method to simulate various potential interest rate paths, with a 30-year default-free coupon-paying bond as the benchmark bond. After the initial simulation of the paths, she customizes the model by adding a constant to all interest rates on all paths to ensure that the average present value for the benchmark bond equals its current market price.

The technique used by Kent to customize the Monte Carlo model is best described as:
questions.explanation:
What Kent Did: Added a constant to all interest rates on all paths. This is the definition of a drift adjustment.

Monte Carlo Model Customization Techniques:
- Drift Adjustment: Add constant to all rates on all paths → This is what Kent did
- Mean Reversion: Set upper/lower bounds; rates move toward forward curve → Not what Kent did
- Benchmarking: Using current spot curve as reference → This is what she's calibrating TO, not the technique she's using

Why A is Correct:
The drift term is a constant added to ensure model prices match market prices. When this technique is used, the model is said to be drift adjusted.

Why C is Wrong:
"Benchmarking the term structure" means using the current spot curve as the reference. That's what Kent is trying to MATCH, not the technique she's using to match it.

Why B is Wrong:
Mean reversion involves setting bounds so rates trend toward implied forward rates over time. Kent isn't setting bounds — she's adding a flat constant.
questions.yourMistake: Confused 'benchmarking the term structure' (using the spot curve as reference) with 'drift adjustment' (adding a constant to all rates to calibrate model prices to market). Benchmarking is what Kent is calibrating TO, not the technique she is using.

questions.title: Equity Swap Cash Flow (Negative Return)
questions.question:
Elaine Azul is evaluating longer-term solutions to reduce Green's exposure to his firm's stock. One approach is to enter into a 3-year equity swap. The proposed equity swap has:
- Semiannual reset
- 30/360 day count
- 2.5% annual fixed rate
- $2 million notional principal

If Green's stock has a -4.5% return (not annualized) over the next six months, the proposed equity swap's net cash flow to Green on its first payment date would be:
questions.explanation:
Equity Swap Structure: Green wants to REDUCE exposure to his stock → He receives fixed, pays equity return.

Step 1: Calculate Fixed Leg (Green Receives)
Fixed Payment = Notional × (Annual Rate / 2)
Fixed Payment = $2,000,000 × (0.025 / 2)
Fixed Payment = $2,000,000 × 0.0125
Fixed Payment = +$25,000

Step 2: Calculate Equity Leg (Green Pays)
Equity Payment = Notional × Equity Return
Equity Payment = $2,000,000 × (-0.045)
Equity Payment = -$90,000

But paying a NEGATIVE amount = RECEIVING money!

Step 3: Calculate Net Cash Flow
Net = Fixed Received + (-Equity Paid)
Net = $25,000 - (-$90,000)
Net = $25,000 + $90,000
Net = $115,000

Key Insight: In equity swaps, "pay equity" with negative return = RECEIVE cash.
Net CF = Fixed Received - (Equity Return × Notional)
Net CF = $25,000 - (-4.5% × $2M) = $25,000 + $90,000 = $115,000
keyFormulas: Net CF = Fixed Received - (Equity Return × Notional)
Negative equity return → PAY becomes RECEIVE
questions.yourMistake: Treated the negative equity return as an outflow rather than an inflow. Wrong logic: Receive Fixed +$25,000, 'Pay' Equity -$90,000 (treated as outflow), Net = $25,000 - $90,000 = -$65,000. Correct logic: When equity return is negative, the equity payer actually receives money.

questions.title: Interest Rate Swap Valuation
questions.question:
Two years ago, White entered into a local market $7 million 5-year interest rate swap with annual resets (30/360 day count), receiving the fixed rate of 1.36% and paying the MRR. Azul determines the value of the swap today using the relevant spot rate data in Exhibit 2.

Exhibit 2:
| Maturity | Spot Rate | Present Value Factor |
| 1 year | 0.262% | 0.9974 |
| 2 years | 0.672% | 0.9867 |
| 3 years | 0.956% | 0.9721 |

The current value of White's interest rate swap is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Swap Valuation Formula (Receive Fixed):
Value = NA × (FS_0 - FS_t) × Sum(PV Factors)

Where:
- NA = Notional = $7,000,000
- FS_0 = Original fixed rate = 1.36%
- FS_t = Current market fixed rate (to be calculated)
- Sum(PV Factors) = Sum of PV factors for remaining life

Step 1: Calculate Sum of PV Factors
Sum(PV) = 0.9974 + 0.9867 + 0.9721 = 2.9562

Step 2: Calculate Current Fixed Swap Rate (FS_t)
FS_t = (1 - Last PV Factor) / Sum(PV Factors)
FS_t = (1 - 0.9721) / 2.9562
FS_t = 0.0279 / 2.9562
FS_t = 0.009438 = 0.9438%

Step 3: Calculate Swap Value
Value = $7,000,000 × (0.0136 - 0.009438) × 2.9562
Value = $7,000,000 × 0.004162 × 2.9562
Value = $86,130

Why A is Wrong (-$148,338): Answer A uses PV factors for years 3, 4, and 5 instead of years 1, 2, and 3.
keyFormulas: Current Fixed Rate = (1 - PV_final) / Sum(All PV Factors)
Swap Value = Notional × (Original Rate - Current Rate) × Sum(PV Factors)
questions.yourMistake: Calculated FS_t incorrectly as the simple average of spot rates: FS_t = (0.262% + 0.672% + 0.956%) / 3 = 0.63%. Then Value = $7M × (1.36% - 0.63%) × 2.9562 = $151,062. Should have used the PV factor formula: FS_t = (1 - PV_final) / Sum(PV Factors).

questions.title: Insurance Combined Ratio
questions.question:
Gordon evaluates the performance of a property and casualty insurance company, Bronx Insurance Company. She calculates the company's combined ratio for the most recent year using the information (in $ millions) presented in Exhibit 2.

Exhibit 2:
| Item | Amount ($ millions) |
| Net premiums written | 3,600 |
| Net premiums earned | 3,200 |
| Loss and loss adjustment expenses | 2,300 |
| Underwriting expenses | 990 |
| Dividends paid to policyholders | 100 |

The combined ratio for Bronx Insurance is closest to:
questions.explanation:
Combined Ratio Formula:
Combined Ratio = Loss Ratio + Underwriting Expense Ratio

Step 1: Calculate Loss and Loss Adjustment Expense Ratio
Loss Ratio = Loss & LAE / Net Premiums EARNED
Loss Ratio = 2,300 / 3,200
Loss Ratio = 71.875%

Step 2: Calculate Underwriting Expense Ratio
Expense Ratio = Underwriting Expenses / Net Premiums WRITTEN
Expense Ratio = 990 / 3,600
Expense Ratio = 27.5%

Step 3: Calculate Combined Ratio
Combined Ratio = 71.875% + 27.5%
Combined Ratio = 99.375% ≈ 99%

Why C is Wrong (103%): Answer C is the Combined Ratio AFTER Dividends: Dividend Ratio = 100 / 3,200 = 3.125%, Combined After Dividends = 99.4% + 3.125% = 102.5% ≈ 103%

Key Memory Aid:
- Loss Ratio = Losses / Premiums EARNED
- Expense Ratio = Expenses / Premiums WRITTEN
- "Losses are EARNED, Expenses are WRITTEN"
keyFormulas: Loss Ratio = Losses / Premiums EARNED
Expense Ratio = Expenses / Premiums WRITTEN
Combined Ratio = Loss Ratio + Expense Ratio
questions.yourMistake: Used Net Premiums WRITTEN for BOTH ratios. Wrong: Loss Ratio = 2,300 / 3,600 = 63.9% (wrong denominator!), Expense Ratio = 990 / 3,600 = 27.5%, Combined = 63.9% + 27.5% = 91.4%. The Loss Ratio denominator should be Premiums EARNED (3,200), not WRITTEN (3,600).

questions.title: Market Manipulation Standards
questions.question:
Susan Li, CFA, an equity research analyst with Maipo Canyon Investment Bank (MCIB), specializes in identifying companies that are likely takeover candidates.

MCIB's proprietary model predicts that a takeover of Godoggo Corporation is highly likely. In a recent report, Li assigned a "Buy" recommendation to Godoggo's stock. Based on the report, one of MCIB's portfolio managers buys a large number of shares in Godoggo for his fund. He subsequently promotes the stock in several online chat rooms by stating, "I have purchased Godoggo stock because our internal research indicates that it is highly likely to be taken over." A week later, the price of Godoggo's stock has doubled and the portfolio manager subsequently sells all the shares of the stock in his fund.

Are the portfolio manager's actions with regard to Godoggo shares a violation of the Standard relating to market manipulation?

choices.text: Yes, because he engaged in transaction-based market manipulation
Yes, because he engaged in information-based market manipulation

questions.explanation:
Standard II(B) Market Manipulation — Two Types:

Transaction-based: Artificial trades to affect price/volume. Did PM do this? NO — bought based on legitimate research.
Information-based: Spreading FALSE rumors to induce trading. Did PM do this? NO — stated true opinion based on report.

Why There's NO Violation:

1. The Purchase Was Legitimate: PM bought based on Li's research report. This is a valid investment reason. Not an attempt to artificially inflate price.

2. The Online Promotion Was Not False: PM stated he bought the stock (true). PM said internal research supports it (true). PM expressed an opinion based on actual analysis.

3. The Subsequent Sale Was Legitimate: Stock doubled — taking profits is normal. PM had valid reason to buy AND sell.

Why C is Wrong: Information-based manipulation requires spreading FALSE rumors. The PM stated facts (he did buy, research does exist), expressed legitimate opinion (takeover likely), and did NOT fabricate information.

Why B is Wrong: Transaction-based manipulation requires trades designed to artificially affect prices. The PM bought based on fundamental research and did not engage in wash trades or painting the tape.

Key Distinction: Sharing TRUE information/opinions does not equal Manipulation. Manipulation requires FALSE statements or artificial transactions. This is a tricky question because the fact pattern LOOKS suspicious, but the Standards focus on whether information was FALSE, not whether someone profited.
questions.yourMistake: Assumed the PM's actions were information-based manipulation because the pattern looked suspicious (buy, promote, sell). However, manipulation requires spreading FALSE information. The PM stated true facts and legitimate opinions based on actual research. Sharing true information is not manipulation under Standard II(B).

questions.title: F-Test for Joint Significance
questions.question:
Sarah Kendall develops a model with three factors to explain weekly returns. She estimates the model for silver and platinum returns using 624 weekly observations.

Kendall gathers the model output for silver returns and tests whether the model explains RET with any statistical significance. She uses the partial ANOVA table results in Exhibit 1 and notes that the critical value of the F-statistic is 3.813 at the 1% significance level and 2.619 at the 5% significance level.

Exhibit 1:
| Source | Degrees of Freedom | Sum of Squares | Mean Squares |
| Regression | 3 | 0.0453 | 0.0151 |
| Residual | 620 | 0.9512 | 0.0015 |
| Total | 623 | 0.9965 | --- |

Do the independent variables jointly contribute to the explanation of silver returns?

choices.text: Yes, at the 5% significance level only
Yes, at both the 5% and 1% significance levels

questions.explanation:
F-Test Formula:
F = MSR / MSE
F = Mean Square Regression / Mean Square Error

Calculation:
F = 0.0151 / 0.0015
F = 10.07

Compare to Critical Values:
- 5% level: Critical Value = 2.619, F-stat (10.07) > 2.619 → YES, significant
- 1% level: Critical Value = 3.813, F-stat (10.07) > 3.813 → YES, significant

Conclusion: Reject H0 at BOTH significance levels → Variables jointly significant at both 5% AND 1%.

Common wrong calculations:
- SSR / MSR = 0.0453 / 0.0151 = 3.0 (between critical values → would give answer B)
- MSE / MSR = 0.0015 / 0.0151 = 0.1 (not significant → would give answer A)
keyFormulas: F = MSR / MSE (Mean Square Regression / Mean Square Error)
questions.yourMistake: Likely calculated F incorrectly, possibly using SSR / MSR = 0.0453 / 0.0151 = 3.0, which falls between the two critical values (2.619 and 3.813), leading to the conclusion of significance at 5% only. The correct F-statistic uses MSR / MSE = 0.0151 / 0.0015 = 10.07.

questions.title: Model Misspecification Tests
questions.question:
Kendall considers platinum returns. After running the model, she tests for model misspecification. The variance inflation factor for each of the independent variables is close to 1.00, and the Breusch-Godfrey test fails to reject the null hypothesis.

Does the testing of the platinum return model indicate model misspecification?

choices.text: Yes, because there is evidence of multicollinearity
Yes, because there is evidence of serial correlation

questions.explanation:
Test Results Analysis:

VIF ≈ 1.00 → Low → NO multicollinearity (VIF > 5 = problem)
Breusch-Godfrey: Fail to reject H0 → NO serial correlation

Breusch-Godfrey Test:
- H0: No serial correlation in residuals
- Fail to reject H0 → No evidence of serial correlation
- This is GOOD — no misspecification

VIF (Variance Inflation Factor):
- VIF ≈ 1 → No multicollinearity
- VIF > 5 → Investigate multicollinearity
- VIF > 10 → Serious multicollinearity problem

Key Rule:
- Breusch-Godfrey: Fail to reject = NO serial correlation = GOOD
- VIF close to 1 = NO multicollinearity = GOOD
keyFormulas: Breusch-Godfrey: Fail to reject H0 = NO serial correlation
VIF close to 1 = NO multicollinearity; VIF > 5 = problem; VIF > 10 = serious
questions.yourMistake: Confused 'fail to reject H0' with 'reject H0'. Fail to reject H0 means no serial correlation (no problem). Reject H0 would mean serial correlation exists (problem). The Breusch-Godfrey null hypothesis is that there is NO serial correlation.

questions.title: Model Selection: AIC vs BIC vs R-squared
questions.question:
Kendall considers alternate model specifications. Her objective is to select the most parsimonious, best-fitting model. Kendall evaluates several goodness-of-fit measures.

Exhibit 2:
| Model | Factors | AIC | BIC | R-squared |
| 1 | FSI | 5.134 | 5.141 | 0.098 |
| 2 | FSI, GPR | 5.132 | 5.153 | 0.103 |
| 3 | FSI, GPR, EPU | 5.139 | 5.160 | 0.106 |

Which of the models for platinum returns should Kendall select based on her objective?
questions.explanation:
Kendall's Objective: "Most parsimonious, best-fitting model"
- Parsimonious = Simplest model that fits well
- Best-fitting = Lowest information criterion

Model Selection Criteria:
- BIC: Best fit + parsimony, Lower = Better, Penalizes complexity HEAVILY
- AIC: Prediction, Lower = Better, Penalizes complexity moderately
- R-squared: Explained variance, Higher = Better, Does NOT penalize complexity

For Parsimony + Best Fit → Use BIC

BIC Values:
- Model 1: 5.141 ← LOWEST
- Model 2: 5.153
- Model 3: 5.160

Model 1 has the lowest BIC → Select Model 1

Why B is Wrong: Model 2 has the lowest AIC (5.132), which is better for prediction purposes. But the question asks for parsimony + fit, which requires BIC.

Key Selection Rules:
- Best fit + Parsimony → BIC
- Best prediction → AIC
- Just explained variance → R-squared (but risk overfitting)
keyFormulas: Parsimony + Fit → BIC (lower = better)
Prediction → AIC (lower = better)
R-squared always increases with more variables — does not penalize complexity
questions.yourMistake: Selected Model 3 based on highest R-squared. But R-squared always increases with more variables, doesn't penalize complexity, and leads to overfitting. The question asked for 'most parsimonious, best-fitting' which requires BIC, not R-squared.

questions.title: Machine Learning Algorithm Selection
questions.question:
As a result of her firm investing in new data sources and technology, Kendall gains access to a wide range of new inputs that could be used to model the commodity market. She decides to utilize this dataset in a machine-learning algorithm with the goal of predicting commodity returns from the complex non-linear data.

Which of the following machine-learning algorithms is best suited to Kendall's goal?
questions.explanation:
Kendall's Goal:
1. Prediction of returns
2. Complex non-linear data

ML Algorithm Selection:
- Neural Networks: Best for Prediction + Non-linear data
- Support Vector Machine: Best for Classification + Linear data
- PCA: Best for Dimension reduction (not prediction)

Why A (Neural Networks) is Correct:
- Goal is prediction (numerical output)
- Data is non-linear
- Neural networks handle complex patterns

Why B (SVM) is Wrong:
- SVM is for classification (categorical output), not prediction
- SVM works best with linear data
- Kendall wants to PREDICT returns, not CLASSIFY

Why C (PCA) is Wrong:
- PCA reduces dimensionality
- PCA doesn't predict — it summarizes/transforms data
- Would be a preprocessing step, not a final model

ML Decision Tree:
Is the goal prediction or classification?
- Prediction (numerical): Linear data → Penalized regression, LASSO; Non-linear data → CART, Random Forest, NEURAL NETWORKS
- Classification (categorical): Linear data → SVM, K-nearest neighbor; Non-linear data → Random Forest
questions.yourMistake: Selected Support Vector Machine, which is for classification (categorical output) with linear data. Kendall's goal is prediction (numerical output) with non-linear data, which points to neural networks.

questions.title: Hedging Pressure Hypothesis
questions.question:
Hansen observes that Crescent's returns in the natural gas sector behaved differently from the other two sectors over the past five years. Hansen gathers prior-year price information for the natural gas market.

| 26 June | 1.795 | 1.795 | 2.338 | 2.546 |

Under the hedging pressure hypothesis, the prices in Exhibit 2 indicate:

choices.text: Excess demand for price protection by producers
Excess demand for price protection by consumers

Hedging Pressure Hypothesis:
- Backwardation (futures < spot): Producers seeking protection (selling forward)
- Contango (futures > spot): Consumers seeking protection (buying forward)
- Flat: Balanced hedging demand

questions.title: CDS Trade P&L Calculation
questions.question:
Three months ago, Arlandi bought $10 million of 5-year protection on Company B through a CDS contract with a duration of 3.7 years. The CDS credit spread has since narrowed from 350 bps to 220 bps currently. Arlandi closes out the trade by selling the CDS contract.

The estimated loss on the CDS trade on Company B is closest to:
questions.explanation:
P&L = Change in Spread × Duration × Notional
P&L = (220 bps - 350 bps) × 3.7 × $10,000,000
P&L = (-130 bps) × 3.7 × $10,000,000
P&L = (-0.013) × 3.7 × $10,000,000
P&L = -$481,000 (LOSS)

Why It's a Loss:
- Arlandi bought protection (bet on spreads widening)
- Spreads narrowed (credit improved)
- Protection buyer loses when spreads narrow

Formula: CDS P&L = Change in Spread × Duration × Notional
Bought protection + spreads narrow = LOSS
keyFormulas: CDS P&L = Change in Spread × Duration × Notional
Bought protection + spreads narrow = LOSS

questions.title: Stock-Based Compensation Tax Effects
questions.question:
Bronx Insurance has a restricted stock unit (RSU) plan for employees. On the grant date at the beginning of the first year, the share price was $6.00 per RSU. At the end of the second year, the share price was $5.00 per RSU. Settlement for the RSUs is made at the end of each year.

During the second year of the RSU plan, Bronx Insurance incurred:
questions.explanation:
Tax Effect of Stock Price Movement:
- Price UP (vest > grant): Tax deduction > Book expense → Excess tax benefit
- Price DOWN (vest < grant): Tax deduction < Book expense → Tax shortfall

Grant price: $6.00
Settlement price: $5.00
Price went DOWN
Tax deduction based on $5.00 < Book expense based on $6.00
Result: Tax shortfall (higher taxable income, higher tax expense)
